title.narrative: Increasing research skills and capacity to support the implementation of national livestock development plans in sub-Saharan Africa

description.narrative: Increasing research skills and capacity to support the implementation of national livestock development plans in sub-Saharan Africa

Livestock development is an important driver for economic development and welfare in low and middle-income countries (LMICs). Within the current global and unified strategy to deliver on the sustainable development goals (SDGs), livestock development is a major component of the agriculture sector and tightly linked to food security and economic development. In both global north and global south, progress in productivity and total transformation (of the entire sector in some cases) required in livestock development, agricultural development and food security continue to rely on key research skills to drive the innovations and generate relevant technologies. In sub Saharan Africa, there are significant gaps in research skills in Genome Technologies and Bioinformatics, Mathematical Modelling of livestock infectious diseases, Quantitative Genetics and Animal Breeding, and Big data in Agriculture. Within the UK bioscience community, a joint BBSRC, MRC and the Society of Biology review (2014-2015) highlighted shortages and vulnerability in key skills including agriculture, food security and research interdisciplinarity. We propose to contribute towards closing these capacity building gaps in research skills and research interdisciplinarity through summer schools and research experience placements in BBSRC-funded Institutes (The Roslin Institute) and in national institutes in LMICs in Africa. To achieve this goal, we have partnered with livestock (agriculture) research and development leaders in African national programs (Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi and Tanzania) to co-develop a 3-years capacity building plan that will focus on i) targeting researchers, postdoctoral scientists and advanced postgraduate students in the UK and LMICs for short term training through summer schools to be held annually in Africa and ii) exchange
research experience and skills enhancement visits through short term (1 month) placements of UK and LMICs. Our interventions have been designed to align with governments’ livestock development strategies of Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania and Malawi which are long term frameworks to support national efforts to meet key targets under the SDGs with the following objectives: i) poverty reduction, ii) food and nutritional security, ii) economic growth, iii) exports and foreign exchange earnings and iv) climate mitigation and adaptation. Our proposal is also aligned with the capacity building efforts already underway through the recently established Centre for Tropical Livestock Genetics and Health (CTLGH). CTLGH is a joint partnership between the Roslin Institute and wider University of Edinburgh, Scotland’s Rural College (SRUC) and the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) with principal offices in Africa and Asia. Through substantive funding from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) and UK Department for International Development (DFID), CTLGH currently support projects focused on livestock research and development focusing on productivity and resilience. CTLGH has already nucleated research expertise and forged collaborations between the UK and target countries and the GCRF-STARS funding offers the opportunity to launch specific training events and research placements aligned to the objectives of the funding secured thus far for livestock development. Our recently-awarded BBSRC Institute Strategic Programmes for 2017-2022 supply the cadre of researchers and ongoing projects to provide exceptional training in these areas.
